title: YSL Montreal Exhibition font
content:
I fell absolutely in love with the font that they used at the Montreal Museum of Fine Arts exhibition of Yves St Laurent’s works.

 ![](http://web.archive.org/web/20080613052725im_/http:/www.typophile.com/files/yslcatalogue_5549.gif)
  
It’s essentially this font but imagine it without the lines to connect the letters.
 [‹ Wedding Invite fonts](http://web.archive.org/web/20080613052725/http:/www.typophile.com/node/46284 "Go to previous forum topic") [MIGHTY HEALTHY TEE font id needed ›](http://web.archive.org/web/20080613052725/http:/www.typophile.com/node/46287 "Go to next forum topic")
author: greenjem

comments.content: I think you’re right. Don’t know why I’ve been squeamish about using Helvetica for years when it’s clearly a great sans serif. Think it’s the right font for an architecture portfolio?
I thought it was the only font for architecture portfolios.
Oh sometimes we make other missteps. I was using [District Thin](http://web.archive.org/web/20080613052725/http:/www.philsfonts.com/freefont.html) but am thinking it wasn’t the best.
